lessons.content:
Trig Ratios

We define $\sin\theta=\frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}}$, $\cos\theta=\frac{\text{adjacent}}{\text{hypotenuse}}$, and $\tan\theta=\frac{\sin\theta}{\cos\theta}$.

Key Identities

  • $\tan\theta \equiv \dfrac{\sin\theta}{\cos\theta}$
  • $\sin^2\theta + \cos^2\theta \equiv 1$

Use these to simplify expressions and prove identities.

lessons.topic: Graphs of sin, cos, tan (degrees & radians)
lessons.content:
Know the shapes and key points. Exact values: $\sin 30^\circ=\tfrac12$, $\cos 60^\circ=\tfrac12$, $\tan 45^\circ=1$.

Use radians: $30^\circ=\tfrac{\pi}{6}$, $45^\circ=\tfrac{\pi}{4}$, $60^\circ=\tfrac{\pi}{3}$.

For $y=a\sin(bx)+c$: amplitude $=|a|$, period $=\dfrac{2\pi}{|b|}$ (for sin/cos), and vertical shift $=c$.

For $y=a\tan(bx)+c$: period $=\dfrac{\pi}{|b|}$.

Use notations $\sin^{-1}x$, $\cos^{-1}x$, $\tan^{-1}x$ for principal values.

Domains for principal values: $\sin^{-1}x\in[-\tfrac{\pi}{2},\tfrac{\pi}{2}]$, $\cos^{-1}x\in[0,\pi]$, $\tan^{-1}x\in(-\tfrac{\pi}{2},\tfrac{\pi}{2})$.
Solve forms $\sin(nx)=k$, $\cos(nx)=k$, $\tan(nx)=k$ in degrees or radians, within a given interval. Example: solve $\sin(2x)=\tfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$ for $0\le x<2\pi$.
